name: Legacy of an icon: Anna May Wong
description: Wong Liu Tsong, known professionally as Anna May Wong, was a film star in the 1920s and 30s who made a career for herself despite racist stereotypes and vilification. Her legacy lives on as she is now being portrayed by contemporary actors on film and TV.

key_work.title: Between two worlds
key_work.last_on_display_place: Australian Centre for the Moving Image
key_work.brief_description: Anna May Wong was tired of the limited and stereotypical roles Hollywood offered her in the 1920s and 30s. Though considered the first Asian American movie star, she was often forced to play the villainous ‘Dragon Lady’ or subservient ‘Lotus Flower’.

start.title: The Good Earth
start.creator_credit: Sidney A. Franklin, Irving G. Thalberg and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
start.brief_description: Set in pre-revolutionary China, Paul Muni plays Wang Lung, a simple peasant farmer who rises to become a prosperous lord. Tragedy pursues him as he betrays his family and neglects the earth he has worshipped. Luise Rainer won an Academy Award for her portrayal of O-Lan, Wang’s devoted wife, a battered slave who grows into a proud, loyal woman. Based on Pearl S. Buck’s Pulitzer Prize winning novel.

end.title: Babylon

end.brief_description: A tale of outsized ambition and outrageous excess, tracing the rise and fall of multiple characters in an era of unbridled decadence and depravity during Hollywood’s transition from silent films and to sound films in the late 1920s.

links.description: Li Jun Li played a character inspired by Anna May Wong, Lady Fay Zhu, in the Damien Chazelle-directed film Babylon. The character was written drawing direct inspiration from the actor’s life, including her move from Hollywood to Europe due to the limitations of her career and the costumes she wears.

The portrayal reflects the growing interest in Wong as a cultural figure, including being the first Asian American woman to be depicted on an American coin in 2021.

end.title: Shanghai Express
end.creator_credit: Josef von Sternberg, Adolph Zukor and Paramount Pictures
end.brief_description: The lightweight plot - an evacuation by train from Peking to Shanghai - is merely the pretext for one of Sternberg’s most successful pieces of stylization, a fruitful collaboration with cinematographer Lee Garmes (and an uncredited James Wong Howe), and writer Jules Furthman. Dietrich plays Shanghai Lily, a ‘coaster’ (a woman who lives by her wits along the Chinese coast) whose scandalous lifestyle is summed up in the films now classic line, ‘It took more than one man to change my name to Shanghai Lily’. Clive Brook’s plays Dietrich’s love interest Captain Donald Harvey, a stuffy Englishman who knew Lily before her infamous lifestyle and is still hurting from her having previously run off on him. Sternberg uses the stop-start cadences of the narrative as a means to evoke the rhythm of the train, while functioning as a kind of time machine confronting the motley group with their pasts as it carries them to their respective fates. However Sternberg’s main point of interest is Dietrich whose status in the film takes on fetishistic proportions, while being gloriously framed and lit in every scene. Cast includes Anna May Wong, Louise Closser Hale, Eugene Pallette, Lawrence Grant. (Awards: Winner, Best Cinematography- Lee Garmes, Academy Awards, 1932)

links.description: After leaving Hollywood for Europe due to being typecast, Anna May Wong starred alongside her rumoured lover, Marlene Dietrich, in Shanghai Express in 1932. Film historians today view her performance as upstaging Dietrich.
